content.value: Studio - Experiences provides a visual editing tool enabling content creators to assemble page layouts using components based on their design system, and to populate them with content from Contentful entries. Experiences enhance structured content with structured design.
Once Experiences is set up by a developer, creators can not only layout new page designs, but they can also create reusable or one-off patterns without the help of developer intervention.
See
Studio - Experiences: Best practices
for in-depth recommendations regarding building with Experiences.
See the internal-only
Studio Internal Roadmap Thinking
article in Confluence for the updated GTM plan.
Updates: FY25, Q2:
Studio now supports CSS units other than
px
, including
em
, and
rem
Users can now rename top-level layer in the Layers tab to provide custom, meaningful names
Studio roles and permissions now allow restricting access to individual components when using the
Edit experiences
access level.
Experiences SDK now supports adding custom breakpoints
Updates: FY25, Q1:
Experiences now supports
three categories of permissions
based on the ability to view experiences, create/edit experiences using components and patterns, and the ability to create and edit patterns
Key characteristics:
Frequent visual adjustments and experimentation:
The ideal customer requires maximum flexibility to create visual variations of certain types of content on a regular basis.

For example, designs vary depending on brand, marketing campaign, and product design. Content creators need the ability to construct these layouts using component pieces in a storytelling manner, either reusing content or creating it on the fly.
They also may desire the ability to experiment or test different design approaches in a rapid manner.
Design-centric approach:
The ideal customer not only recognizes the importance of a design system, but embraces it as core to how they approach their digital experiences.
Cross-functional collaboration:

The ideal customer's digital teams not only understand the design system and communicate using a shared language to describe its components, but also the designers, content creators, and developers collaborate when making updates to ensure business needs are met and frontend build requirements are respected.
See
Studio - Experiences: Best practices
guide for a discussion of recommended use cases and how to help customers determine a good fit.
Experiences only supports React based frontends, with some further limitations.
See
Implementation details
for more.
See the
Studio - Experience: Best practices
article for a full discussion of guiding principles for working with Experiences. It presents recommended ways of working in four steps:
Identifying the use case for Experiences
Considering how the content model should be used
Configuring the Experience interface
Assembling an experience
Technical qualifying criteria
The Experiences SDK is written in Typescript and supports React-based applications. No other languages or frameworks are supported at this time.
If the customer is using NextJS, a popular React frontend framework, they can use both server and client side rendering with the Pages router. If using App Router, the module rendering the
<ExperienceRoot>
component must use the
`use client`
directive, otherwise the Experiences SDK code used to fetch the experience can be rendered server-side. See
Using Experiences with NextJS
in the developers wiki and
Rendering: Client Components
in the NextJS documentation for more.
Experiences does not support
React Server Components
at this time.
The customer‚Äôs application must support being rendered in an iframe. If the customer is using a
CSP policy
, they will need to add
https://app.contentful.com
as an allowed domain.
Set up
Enabling Studio Experiences in Spaces
Configure Preview for an Experience
Set up the Experiences SDK
Supported React frameworks
Next JS includes additional
set up requirements
depending on the routing method used
Astro/React is supported, with additional set up requirements. Dev docs to be updated.
Known implementation limitations

The Experiences SDK requires that an instantiated Contentful Delivery API (CDA) or Contentful Preview API (CPA) client is passed as an argument when retrieving an experience. While a frontend application may use GraphQL, it must still use the CDA/CPA with Experiences.
Currently, React Native does not work with the Experiences SDK.
Chrome is the only supported browser. With other browsers, users may be unable to access the Experiences tab, among other issues.
There is no integration with design system applications like Figma to allow import of design components into Experiences.
Developers cannot register custom widgets with components, but a select list can be used to provide a list of options to creators.
Registered components can be of type
Object
, however this type was added to accommodate requirements for images, and is not as tightly type-controlled as other types, like text or boolean. Providing a field of type
Object
in a component could lead to unpredictable results for creators.
The default Image component provided by Studio uses the CSS background property rather than the
<picture>
tag, which a commonly used element supporting responsive images.
Relationship to Delivery and Preview APIs

The Experiences SDK uses the Delivery and Preview APIs to retrieve experiences and make that data available to the frontend application. Direct calls to retrieve experiences through the CDA or CPA, or by using Contentful client libraries, will return experiences data. This is useful for retrieving any custom fields that may have been added to the Experience type.
Caching
Experiences are cached on the CDA, and are purged on publish/unpublish/archive events.
React component structure

Because Experiences provides a design-centric approach to page-building, developers will need to take a similar approach when building components in their frontend framework. One method of designing the frontend application is to use a 1:1 mapping of content types in Contentful to React components, e.g. a Callout content type in Contentful will have a corresponding
<Callout>
component in React. This
<Callout>
component is built expressly to expect the fields present in its content type, such as a heading, text, and display type. This works well until we decide we want to reuse the
style
of the Callout for a different content type, or in a different context. With 1:1 mapping, we would need to create a new React component to handle these new use cases.

By using a design-centric approach, we would instead construct our React components to accept an interface describing what primitive types are allowed for each field in the component, and a resolver function to map them. Our Callout example would expect a String for the heading, String for the text, and String for the display type. We could then feed this component any content we want for each of these fields as long as they meet the type criteria, and therefore reuse the style of the Callout wherever we need while feeding it the content we want.

In short, the React component must be agnostic to its content source, as long as its interface requirements are met, to make proper use of Experiences. This also enables building the application components as a separate design package, in a similar manner as
Forma 36
, that can be reused across projects. Furthermore, there is currently no good way to mix and match 1:1 and design-centric content type to component structure.
Notes & gotchas

Like with content types, additional fields can be added to Experience types under the content modeling tab in Contentful Platform. Any fields added here will appear in the Settings tab in the experience, along with the default Title and Slug fields. These fields are available in the experience object which is returned from the
useFetchBySlug()
function.

Built-in components, such as Heading and Button, can be overridden by creating a custom component with the same machine name as the built-in one. In this case, you must pass the spread props from the original component to the custom one because that is what the SDK will expect. Instead, we recommend
disabling the built-in component
and creating a new one with a different machine name to avoid any confusion, errors, or future problems.
In-depth analysis of the following competitors is available on
Ascend Academy
Builder.io
Uniform
Netlify Create
Webflow
Framer
Other competitors include:
Sanity's Presentation
tool is a visual editor claiming to support structured content, design guidelines, and workflows
Shopstory

provides a visual builder for use with Contentful, Contentstack, Amplience, and Sanity. It works by providing a custom field in Contentful content types that opens a visual builder. Content created in the builder operates like manual content in Studio - Experiences. It does not allow binding to Contentful entries like Experiences does.

Developer documentation

(Help Center)

on Ascend Academy

content.value: Browse third-party products from technical partners and other vendors.
External references
and
delivery functions

allow customers to orchestrate content within Contentful from third-party systems, such as PIMs and DAMs. This allows authors to directly reference content from those external systems in Contentful entries, and allows developers to make a single API call to Contentful to retrieve both Contentful and third-party data.
Prior to this feature, Contentful was limited to
orchestrating content and content types between different spaces
, and any external data retrieval had to be handled by the customer's architecture.
Delivery functions
The power behind external references, delivery functions are
serverless functions

that run on Contentful's infrastructure allowing custom code to run in the same path as GraphQL requests. Customers create a custom app using a delivery function that targets a field on a content type. The external data queried by the delivery function is attached the the GraphQL schema using the "_data" suffix.
External references

External references is an umbrella term for all apps that use delivery functions under the hood, or rather, that use a GraphQL resolver made for a specific provider. When installing an app with an external reference, customers are essentially using a pre-made delivery function with a connected source.
The current marketplace apps supporting external references are:
Shopify
CommerceTools
Cloudinary
High level planning for orchestration can be found in slide 33 of the
Orchestration PSA
Beta - EAP

Delivery functions are one piece of creating a larger framework for third party orchestration. The EAP is meant to gather learnings and find opportunities to commoditize features. Key focus areas are:
Backwards compatibility
Simple opt-in and gradual adoption
Minimal customer impact
GraphQL before REST; GraphQL adoption is growing faster than REST
Demonstrate u
se the Contentful platform to provide managed resolvers
GA - Spring Launch '24
Still under development, but tentatively scheduled to include the following:
Access to execution logs to aid in development and troubleshooting
Ability to execute delivery functions in the management context
Potential future updates

Delivery function usage insights available to customers so that they can understand performance and optimize their utilization of delivery functions. These insights would also be used for overage billing purposes.
Delivery functions are ideal for customers who:
Already u
se GraphQL to fetch data from Contentful
Have an ecommerce use case, or otherwise r
equire integration with third-party data, whether it is from a PIM or DAM, legacy CMS, custom data source, or any other API
Are already familiar or willing to familiarize themselves with creating custom apps
Have limited development resources for backend services; delivery functions can eliminate the need to maintain custom architecture to handle third-party integration
Are testing new architecture and require a simplified way of connecting third-party systems
Are transforming from a monolithic to microservice architecture
Value a native-feeling interaction with third-party data while editing content in
Contentful
All customers requiring integration with third-party data in Contentful entries
The updated entry card view provides more information to editors, and is not dependent on the configuration of the individual field parameters
Editors are able to build the complete experience in Contentful while still gaining insight into third-party content
Delivery functions do not have to be used with third-party orchestration, although we generally focus on those use cases
As long as it's a Javascript function, it can be run with delivery functions
Since delivery functions live on Contentful's infrastructure, customers do not need to think about their own hosting or scalability issues
Customers who wish to simplify development workflows; with fewer systems to query in the frontend application, maintenance becomes easier
Customers who use REST as their primary delivery API; at the moment, delivery functions are only available when using GraphQL.
Customers can use REST in combination with GraphQL, but teams most often prefer using one or the other
Some customers have high security standards and require more advanced verification of requests
This is currently not supported but is being
looked into by Ecosystem product line
Customers should set the
cache TTL for fields with external references

to meet their business needs. For example, a Contentful entry that references third-party commerce data should likely break cache frequently to ensure the commerce data (e.g. pricing info, product descriptions) is fresh.
Delivery functions

Delivery functions require a GraphQL schema. In Contentful, that schema is generated upon saving a Content Type. The "extended schema" for external data sources are always attached to a Contentful field, which means that your app needs to be in the field location and the "Resolve content on delivery" flag checked.
Resolving external references are set via an instance parameter on every content type field the app is configured for. There is no global setting for resolving data on all field app installations.
Step by step guide
Choose a content type and a short text field that should use your delivery function
Open up your terminal
Create a new demo app with delivery functions - you can use the existing Harry Potter example via
npx @contentful/create-contentful-app@latest potter-demo --typescript --delivery-function --example hosted-delivery-function-potterdb
- For a clean demo, you can remove example and only run
npx @contentful/create-contentful-app@latest potty-about-pottter --typescript --delivery-function

Create your app definition via the CLI using create-app-definition or in the web app
- The EAP flag under Delivery Function will not disappear until your app is built
Switch to the directory via cd potter-demo
Build your whole app with
npm run build
- You can build out the delivery function separately by running
npm run build:delivery-functions
Upload your app with
npm run upload
Install the app into your space
Go to your Content Type, and select a field which the potter-demo app is assigned to. Change the appearance to potter-demo, and make sure "Resolve Content on Delivery" is ‚úÖ
You can only have one delivery function per custom Contentful app defined
A delivery function has a maximum execution time of 5 seconds
Delivery functions are only available for private apps
Delivery functions are not retried if they time out
Rate limits for the respective platforms apply
Delivery function can only be applied to
short text
field types

All in all, Contentful's goal with delivery functions is to create an easy lift for developers. While other solutions often require a rip-and-replace approach to integrate their data orchestration, Delivery Functions are meant to be quick and easy to you add on top of your current Contentful implementation.
Netlify Connect
Netlify has released their own GraphQL resolver that aims to orchestrate content from any data source. It's a rebrand of
Gatsby's plugin library
and requires the customer to use Gatsby's delivery model while also only being able to have
data synced on the production environment
. Netlify Connect does however react to data that is updated in the external system, where Contentful does not.
You can find all product team's analysis of the competitive landscape
in slide 43 of the Orchestration PSA

The
Workflows app
allows customers to govern their content operations within Contentful by defining the stages through which entries of selected content types pass throughout their lifecycle, such as
Draft
Needs review
, or
Ready for publication
. At each stage, customers can determine what team members should be involved, what actions need to be taken, and who is able to complete those actions.
Key features include the ability to:
Define custom Workflow steps to satisfy any content lifecycle needs
Assign permissions for each step based on individual users or Teams
Send email or Slack notifications upon step changes to assigned users or Teams
Block publication until steps are complete
Add comments or automatically create Tasks upon step change
Why Workflows?
A well-designed content workflow can streamline the content creation process, improve team collaboration, and ultimately result in higher quality content. The
Workflows app
brings customer content operations closest to where the content lives and helps ensure all stakeholders have visibility into the state of content and are able to work together seamlessly.
See the full
Workflows roadmap
in Jira, under team Homer.
Adding Microsoft teams notification as a Workflow step action is currently under development and undergoing internal testing.
NOTE:
The Workflows app is
only available
on Premium and above plans, with separate entitlements for each.
Predefined content operations:
Customers who have a defined workflow process, or are developing a content operations strategy, and wish to optimize their collaboration and approval methods.
Regulated industries:
Customers operating in highly regulated industries, such as healthcare or finance, who require strict governance of content creation.
Large teams / complex operations:
Customer with large editorial teams, or complex creation and approval processes.
Customers with existing content workflows outside of Contentful who wish to implement similar content governance within Contentful.
Customers who require content entry or reviews across different teams, such as SEO, marketing, legal, design, or 3rd party agency partner teams.
Customers who require strict separation of concerns between creating, editing, and publishing content.
Customers who translate or localize content and require editorial governance, such as integration with a
translation management service
Customers who have a more structured or process-heavy method of collaboration (in contrast to mentions and comments, like in a Google Doc experience).
Customers who have a large number of 'draft' or 'changed' entries and wish to better identify content status.
Advanced workflows, such as requiring very specific step change permissions (only move to Step Y without any other one, conditional workflows step movements).

Relies too much on third-party integrations and uses localization partners. It is also not recommended to use workflows if different teams have different workflows on the same content type. An example could be localised and global teams that work in the same space, on the same content types but have different workflows.
The customer has a Releases content editing experience (Workflows are not connected with Releases that are part of Launch).

Only a small part of the editorial process is in Contentful and the customer has a smaller team (less than 3 people) or prefers to use unstructured, ad-hoc collaborative tools like comments, mentions, and tasks.
Recommended Workflows options
Select the ‚ÄúAutomatic start for new entries‚Äù option to ensure your Workflow is applied. Otherwise, using the Workflow will be optional.
Block publishing in each step except for the final one. Otherwise, your users may be able to end the Workflow early.
Encourage your content creators to add comments when they change Workflow steps. This will help provide clarity for all users.
Use
Teams
to manage step permissions and notifications more easily
You can generate multiple Tasks for a single Workflow step. This may be helpful if several actions are required.
In addition to Slack, email, and Tasks, your developers can create new step actions with a
custom app
and
App Actions
Test new Workflows in lower
environments
with team members before deploying to production
Roles and permissions
Only users with Admin permissions are able to install the app.

Governance settings applied within the Workflows app will override permissions set within a Role. For example, an Author role with permission to publish a Blog Post entry will still be blocked from publishing a Blog Post that is in a Workflow state that restricts publishing.
Any governance settings created within the Workflows app do not apply to Admins. Incomplete required fields and open Tasks will still prevent publishing for Admins, however.
Environments
Workflows are environment specific. Currently there is no option to copy Workflows from one environment to another.
Workflows are attached to the environment
alias
name and not to the targeted environment name. This complicates blue-green deployment because Workflows, Tasks, and Comments will not be cloned into new environments.
Using the Workflows app
Workflows API:
Get all workflows definitions:
Create a workflow:
Complete a workflow:
One workflow per content type and entry
Max 10 workflows per environment
Max 20 steps in a single Workflow
Currently only supports Slack, Tasks and email as step actions (MS Team integration is under development)
Workflows are not cloned when an environment is cloned. This will preclude a customer from using both Workflows and
blue-green deployments
with environments.
Content must still be manually published; there is no action to auto-publish content upon step completion
Creating a Workflow via the Content Management API is not straight forward. One cannot just use the GetWorkflow definition JSON response to create a new Workflow.
Workflows are not locale-aware, and therefore customers cannot assign a Workflow to only apply to a certain locale in a given entry. Instead, it applies to all locales simultaneously.
In general, managing Workflows using the API is cumbersome, and therefore
decreasing implementation time and easing maintenance programmatically is limited.

content.value: Visual Modeler an interactive way to visually build a content model and easily collaborate on the changes with team members. It streamlines the entire content modeling process by bringing planning, building, testing, and iterating into a single workflow. It shortens the overall modeling cycle, where users can tweak and refine their content models as they go.

With Visual Modeler, editorial teams can have confidence that the content architecture meets their needs and ‚Äî most importantly ‚Äî allows them to leverage the right model to deliver impactful digital experiences.
FY24 Q4
Export image of Visual modeler
FY25 Q1-Q2
Discovery/Research:
Modeling Recommendations/Methodologies (AI ‚ú®)
Content types generated from a URL
Best practices of modeling (recommendation engine)
Unstructured to structured content
All Contentful customers should be leveraging the Visual Modeler.
Developers, coordinators, and designers
who draft content types and want to collaboratively build and manage a content architecture and get timely feedback from editors.
Editors, contributors, and marketers

who review models and give feedback, are the target segment. They want to have a simple and easy-to-use model to have a great editing experience in their day-to-day work and reduce their cognitive load.
Getting started with building a model
Reviewing and collaborating on a model with team members
Refining the model, extending, and scaling
Overly complex content models
Teams can see how complex their model is but looking at section may be challenging at this time
Editing atomic style content types
Use the Visual Modeler to build, collaborate and review on a content model.
The
tool can be helpful when auditing a content model and reviewing if a model meets best practices.
It is still recommended that teams make content model adjustments on "lower" environments and use tools like Merge and/or the CLI to manage content type changes between environments.
No technical knowledge required.
Customers can access this via the Content Model tab and use the
Visual Modeler
button to open the experience.
View mode

¬†‚Äî Allows you to view your content model, individual content types, and fields, but not make any changes.¬†In view mode, users can explore the content model, fields available and how content types relate to one another.
Edit mode
¬†‚Äî Allows you to update your content model ‚Äã‚Äãby adding new content types, fields, and references. All changes to your content model are immediately saved. Once edit mode is enabled, users can:
Create new content types
Add new fields (name and field type, field settings are still managed in the content type editing interface)
Share Visual Modeler with other users for collaboration
Users should use Merge App and/or the CLI to
migrate content type changes between environments.

Users who don't have permissions to edit the content model can  still view the Visual Modeler by receiving a "Share" (located in the top right of the Visual Modeler) link from a user who does have content model edit permissions.
External Documentation
Visual Model layout is not saved after user adjustments - [BEGIN WORKED ON]
No draft state of a content type, changes are made immediately
Editing only allow for the basic creation of fields ‚Äì name and type, must use content type edit page to set addition field settings
Large content models may not display and can be challenging to collaborate on
User's that don't have content model edit access, must be provided a "share" link from a user who has edit access in order to see Visual Modeler. There is no way for them to discover it on their own
Contentstack:
Visualizer
Hygraph:
Does not have a visualization tool but has a solid
guide
on content modeling

With the edit mode active, changes to your content model are automatically saved. In order to not affect the master environment, make sure to switch to a non-production environment or deactivate the edit mode.

This may be a new experience for editors, contributors, and marketers to participate in content model collaboration. A tool like this may help make the process be less intimidating and encourage more collaboration between teams. It is important for Contentful to advocate for this collaboration across teams as the most successful content models have a buy-in from the users who create the content.

content.value: During Alpha release, Experience Builder will not be fully formed, and several interactions will either feel clunky or be nonexistent. See
Known Limitations
for more.
Detailed instructions for setup are available on the
Experience Builder Wiki
and
Developer Docs
Currently, Experience Builder only supports React, but other frameworks may be planned for future releases.
Only available as a private release to selected
design partners
Experience Builder SDK
An
npm
package providing a streamlined way of integrating with Experience Builder. Detailed documentation can be found on the
Experience Builder Wiki
and
Developer Docs
Canvas
The main UI area of the Experience Builder. Components that are exposed to Experience Builder can be dragged and dropped in this Canvas.
Localization

Field-level localization is supported, however entry-level localization is not. Components in Experience Builder can only be bound to a single entry, therefore localized fields on a single entry will resolve properly for a given locale. There is no way to bind a single component to multiple entries.
UI Templates (final name TBD)
What It Does
: Allows users to save and reuse design elements, reducing redundancy and accelerating the content creation process.
How It Works

:¬† Users have the capability to craft templates by combining atomic elements such as Headings, Descriptions, and Images. Upon saving, these assembled templates ‚Äîlike a 'Banner' template, for instance ‚Äî become reusable across various projects. This effectively decouples the user interface from the content, allowing for greater flexibility and consistency.
Benefits
: Streamlines the design process by making reusable elements readily available. This contributes to maintaining design consistency while expediting project timelines.
Advanced-Data Binding
What It Does
: Eliminates the need to perform data binding each time a new layout is created.
How It Works
: The feature intelligently recognizes patterns and similarities in layout structures and automates the data binding process where applicable.
Benefits
: Saves time and reduces the margin of error in binding data to UI components. It also makes the system more scalable for complex projects.
Improved Navigation and Discoverability & Component Management
What It Does
: Provides a centralized platform to manage by creating a new ‚Äòexperience‚Äô tab ( similar to the existing ‚Äòcontent‚Äô tab ), update, and monitor all UI components in use across
How It Works
: An admin interface offers an organized view of all available UI components, from atomic to molecular levels. This is integrated with a version control system to track changes and updates.
Benefits
Streamlines the maintenance and updating process of UI components.
Ensures that only approved and up-to-date components are in circulation, reducing issues related to deprecated or conflicting components.
Enables sharing of components between projects and teams, increasing efficiency and collaboration.
Governance - Roles and Permissions
Currently, there are no permission constraints on the system.  For example, all users of Experience Builder can change the pixel values of padding and margins.
With the right roles and permissions, designers and developers can ensure what settings are exposed to which users.  This is essential to keep the designs conforming to the brand guidelines.
3rd Party Orchestration
With third-party orchestration, data/content from other systems can be utilized directly in Experience Builder.  This will streamline the experience.
Sidebar App Extension
Customers will be able to create Experience Builder-specific sidebar extensions to help with their specific use cases that are not covered out of the box.

internalName.en: Exp Builder - Known Limitations > Complex use cases

label.en: Complex use cases may find the system unwieldy

content.value: In its alpha stage, the drag-and-drop feature set may not be comprehensive enough to handle intricate layouts or complex functionalities that some projects might require. For example, creating a deeply nested component tree might require too many drag and drops.
Implications
: Users might struggle with the limitations in the drag-and-drop interface, which may not allow for more complex interactions or design patterns.

internalName.en: Studio Exp - Known Limitations > Cumbersome data-binding

content.value: Data binding must be performed for each field, requiring multiple clicks can take considerable time to create larger experiences.
Currently, binding to a reference and multi-refrence fields is not possible.
Implications:
Binding requires two steps. First the content type must be selected, and then the field needs to be selected. It can be easy to miss field selection.
It adds an extra layer of manual work, slowing down the project development cycle.
Inconsistencies could arise, especially if different people are involved in the data-binding processes across different parts of the project.
Experiences does not yet support cross-space references, Contentful Functions, or native data-pickers for third-party data (e.g. DAM).

internalName.en: Studio Exp - Known Limitations > Live Preview

content.value: Contentful's Live Preview requires a strict understanding of every field in a React component in order to connect it to a content type to enable live editing. Due to this, there is often a tight coupling between a React component and the content type that is not necessary, and in fact could impede use of the same React component in both Live Preview and Studio.
This potential conflict is under review, and may be solved by a planned feature for Live Preview called Auto-tagging.
Creators must bind content from entries using field level localization.
Entry-level localization is not supported, nor is it possible to localize manual content added in the Experience.

internalName.en: Exp Builder - Known Limitations > Moving components

content.value: Moving components can be challenging right now in the Canvas. The only way to do it is in the sidebar on the left. The component that needs to be moved has to be clicked for a second and then it can be dragged.

internalName.en: Studio Exp - Known Limitations > No auto save

content.value: Unlike the Contentful web app, Experiences does not automatically save content changes.
Creators must remember to save any changes manually.

internalName.en: Exp Builder - Known Limitations > Cannot change section text color

content.value: Experience Builder comes with a section container. The background color can be changed however the text color cannot.

internalName.en: Exp Builder - Known Limitations > Confusing drag/drop

content.value: It is currently difficult to see exactly where the dragged component will be placed in the Canvas causing creators to guess and retry component placement.
Adding children to a component is similarly challenging.

internalName.en: Studio Exp- Known Limitations > Max number of component children

label.en: Visual cue on max number of component children

content.value: There is no way for content authors to discover how many maximum number of children a component allows.

internalName.en: Studio Exp - Known Limitations > Layer name

content.value: Custom naming of layers can facilitate navigating the component tree. This feature is not currently available, but is planned for a future release.
Configuring custom breakpoints is not yet possible, but is planned for a future release

When speaking with customers about Workflows, you can use the following script:
I noticed you haven‚Äôt fully used Workflows in your Contentful Spaces yet and wanted to discuss that with you today.

From the customers that have adopted Workflows, they‚Äôve seen increased governance, a quicker speed to publish content with defined processes and automations, and greater transparency and collaboration throughout the content lifecycle.

Does this sound like something your organization could use? Could we set up some time with you and the relevant people to discuss it further an how you could implement Workflows in under two hours without developers?
Importantly, the talking points are around:
Increased Governance:
Admins can define permissions on publishing and editing throughout stages and explicitly lay out the steps to create content. Additionally, the History of a Workflow is tracked and can be referenced.
Automation:
With integrations to email, Tasks, and Slack, you can automate the assignment of Tasks to different individuals with Workflows.
Once the customer has agreed to discuss Workflows with you, utilize the following materials to conduct the call.
Adoption Playbooks Customer Facing Deck: Workflows
CSM Demo Guide: Workflows - FY24 Q4
After the call, share the
Plan to implement: Workflows
guide with the customer.
Customers may cite the following reasons for not exploring Workflows. The associated responses can help move the conversation forward.

fieldExpert.en: Omer Abdul Maroof, Senior Technical Project Manager

content.value: Currently, Contentful supports translating content at the
field-level

. This means that when an entry is published, the content for all locales on that entry will also be published, i.e. in a synchronized manner. As a result, customers are unable to manage separate workflows for localized content by allowing the localized portions of a field to be published at separate times.
Traditionally, we have recommended using
entry-level localization

patterns to achieve asynchronous publishing of localized content, however this can complicate content governance and integration with translation management systems. While entry-level localization patterns will likely persist to support regionalization (i.e. different content per region, which may also be localized), we expect that customers using entry-level patterns to achieve asynchronous locale publishing can switch to using field-level with this feature. This should improve the editing experience for those customers by reducing the number of nested entries.
Contentful Locale-based publishing will allow customers to publish entries for the default locale plus any number of additional locales at different times.
This
Confluence board
outlines the approach to user story mapping and thoughts toward future features.
Important dates
Starting
, customers may join early Beta testing by
completing this form
There is no confirmed date yet, but internally we anticipate Summer 2024 for GA.
In discovery
Product currently is performing discovery concerning:
How entries with multiple locale statuses can be integrated with the Launch app
How will locale based publication be accommodated in the Contentful Management API
Locale-based publishing will be available to Premium and Premium Plus customers.
The GA release of Locale-based publishing will be suited for customers who:
Use at least two locales in a single space
Currently use Entry-level localization to allow separate publishing of different locales for the same entry
Currently use Field-level localization, but struggle with its publishing constraints, such as being forced to publish all locales at the same time
Organize their content teams according to region
Currently use the
Incentro A-sync Localiser app

attempts to allow publishing asynchronously using field-level localization, however since it stores all localized data for all fields in a single JSON field, it presents challenges when operating at scale and introduces technical debt.
During the Beta stage, some customers will be able to test the feature in exchange for feedback. Customers may ask to join Beta testing by
completing this form
. See also this
list of potential customers
The customer uses the same content model for all of its locales, publishes content in its default locale, and needs the flexibility to publish each locale separately for the same entry
As this feature is new, customers participating in Alpha stage testing should be aware of the
current limitations
Customer uses different content models for its regional markets e.g. the content type structure for its landing page in en-US differs from the home page content type structure used in es-es.
For Beta release, this feature is only suitable for customers willing to test the product in an unfinished state. See
Limitations
Since the Workflows app will and Tasks will block publishing of an entry for all locales, customers must define practices for governing async locales publishing in another manner
Use with content models that are shared across regions
Ensure roles and permissions are properly defined for different locales to allow separate editorial teams to manage locales independently of one another
The plan should be to publish content in all available locales. If a locale is no longer required for a content type, it should be disabled in that types fields.
Locale-based publishing can be configured at the environment-level. Encourage customers to clone master and test the feature on that environment prior to using it on the master environment.
Current public information on localization is available in
Localization with Contentful
Migration from entry level to field level localization

Customers who are using entry level localization to achieve asynchronous locale publishing may find that they can change to using field level with this feature. Migration will require developer assistance, and should make use of the Contentful CLI, as reviewed in
Scripting migrations with the Contentful CLI
Un-publishing an entry will un-publish all locales
Workflow states and Tasks will block publishing for the entire entry
Content List View will only show the state of most advanced state of the changed locale.  On hovering over the entry, the status of the rest of the locales can be seen.
Internal competitor analysis
See this
Miro board
used by the product team to review competitors.
Strapi

Internationalization plugin
must be installed to manage the content in multiple locales. Only content in one locale is shown at one time, similar to how it happens in
Contentful Compose app
You can copy the content in the present locale from another locale. Also, different locales can have different page structures within the same entry.

Audit logs provide customers with detailed reports of events that take place within their Contentful spaces -- such as changes to roles, invitations sent to new users, or deleted entries -- allowing visibility into the history of actions taken by their Users for monitoring and analysis purposes.
Audit logs are enabled at the organization level, and logging will occur for all spaces within that org.
The audit logs feature securely transfers this information to the customer's
AWS S3
bucket, which is a simple data service provided by Amazon.
EAP (Spring Launch 2024)

Customers participating in the EAP must be set up for audit logs delivery through a manual process, and therefore the number of participating customers will be limited at the start. Gradually, more customers will be invited to join. The following features are available in the EAP release:
Logs are sent to the customer's AWS S3 bucket in the form of a CSV file
Logs are sent every 24 hours

Data retention on the Contentful side is tentative. Once the audit logs have been successfully sent to the customer‚Äôs storage, Contentful will only retain the audit log data for a short duration of time (days).
Team Moi will work on a trust basis with any customer contact to coordinate set up, regardless of the role assigned to that contact in their Contentful Organization.
The logs will capture update and deletion actions on the following entities:
GA (Fall Launch 2024)
There is no concrete roadmap defined for GA at this time
Under consideration are:
I
mproving the content included in audit logs (for example, recording when an entity is created, oS Organization-level activity).
S
upporting more cloud storage options (ex: Azure, Google Cloud) or more specialized storage options (ex: DataDog, New Relic)
Enable self-service for customers set up and enable audit logs on their own without a Contentful engineer
Supporting EU data residency
Audit logs are only available to V3 Premium and Premium Plus customers
Customers with active AWS accounts and proper configuration of IAM roles and permissions (an AWS S3 bucket is required)
Large enterprise customers in regulatory industries (ex: finance, healthcare)
Customers who require granular insights into changes made their Contentful organization
Customers seeking a way to investigate incidents or perform security audits
Gain security audit insights, such as to review user account modification.
Ex: a user gains admin access unexpectedly, which may indicate a security breach that requires investigation
Operational oversight such as monitoring user activities and system changes to ensure they align with company policies and standards
Ex: Maintain content accountability by tracking who published a piece of content, when it was published, or if unauthorized changes were made to critical data (such as financial data, reports)
Take preventative measures when actions or changes have been taken inadvertently or have had adverse effects
Ex: Increased visibility could aid in recognizing the need to update roles and permissions or to introduce tighter approval workflows

Customers hoping to use audit logs for official compliance purposes.  Audit logs do not comply with any industry standard regulations, and Contentful recommends to refer to these logs as helpful, detailed reports rather than compliance data

Last published date of an entry. We understand that some customers want to see when an entry was last published, so they can keep track of old content and then review it. This is not a goal for audit logs.

View history of activity. We know customers want to see the activity that has happened around various entities such as entries, content types, permissions, and so on. They want to be able to view when something last changed, what changed, and who made that change. And they want to see this in context, specific to the entry they look at. Audit logs won‚Äôt offer that, but it opens up that possibility later on.
Providing the logs to customer's AWS buckets allows them to retain the data for as long as needed and apply the same rules, policies, and access as they do with other forms of data.
From AWS, customers can send audit logs data to dedicated monitoring tools to perform  analysis using their existing tools, such as Datadog or Splunk.

During the EAP phase, the delivery of audit logs is a manual process. The customer must set up their AWS S3 bucket, send the AWS details to Contentful (team Moi directly) and then a Contentful engineer in team Moi will configure audit logs for the customer. Moi will  send the customer a notification once this is complete.
Customer steps :
Within AWS:
Create an AWS S3 bucket
Create a new IAM policy
Create a new IAM role
Attached the policy to the role
Configure the S3 bucket policy
Send a list of AWS details to Contentful
S
ee the
Audit logs
EAP configuration details for more.
During EAP, customers can request cancellation of audit logs the delivery by sending an email to
biz-team-moi+audit+logs@contentful.com

The audit logs content currently is quite technical, which reduces the number of people who can quickly make sense of what is included. For example, actions are shown as HTTP request methods (like PUT or PATCH) instead of non-technical actions like update or delete. We are considering making the content less technical as we iterate.
Changes are only tracked at the space level. Org and user level tracking is planned for the future.

Creation events are not shown in the audit logs we send to customers. For example, if a user creates a new entry, that action will not appear in the audit logs customers receive. We do record that activity internally, but because we don't yet have the ID of the entity that was created, we decided not to include these creation events yet. Creation events are planned to be included in the future.
During EAP, we only support AWS as a storage option. We are considering other cloud storage options (MS Azure or Google Cloud) or more specialized storage (like DataDog) for the future.
There is no user interface at the moment, and we likely will not include one in 2024. This is being considered for 2025.
Event details limitations:

Only the user ID (Ex: 2EHL4afAmn1k10yd6dJxcl), and not the user name or email, is included for each action. This means that during an investigation a person must manually look up which user corresponds to a given ID. This is under consideration for improvement.

To understand what entity has changed, a reviewer must know how to interpret Contentful URL structures. For example, the following URL corresponds to an asset in space 06mz2w7awayu and the master environment:
/spaces/06mz2w7awayu/environments/master/assets/38w90XPrAhwd60MOaO6rHN
The column "request_query" is now always empty. We are looking at how we can surface information there, but it is complicated.
Filtering and searching is limited and requires additional data manipulation to find exact entities
Bulk actions are not showing up in the audit logs. We are looking to see what we can do to improve this later.
See this
Confluence article
for full competitor analysis.

In summary, most direct Contentful competitors offer some form of audit logs, especially among enterprise-focused solutions. Typically these offer real-time logs and data retention periods between 30-90 days.
Many competitors also integrate with third-party services like Splunk and Datadog for extended log management, with CSV exports being the most common method.

content.value: Determine how much asset bandwidth could be saved if the customer were to use transformations. You can view an asset by copying the contents of the
Image
column and prepending the following URL structure:
https://images.ctfassets.net/
For example, the asset in the below image has a URL of:
https://images.ctfassets.net/6pezt69ih962/1ePoDY3XIuYleBQGNKFOTS/35de41a77844d9c3da954074021deeb3/The_Hunt_-_Hero
When we load that image in a browser, we can view the image just as it‚Äôs delivered to the front end application.
If we tried downloading the image, we would see the JPG image is 38KB in size. While that sounds small, remember that this image was fetched 392,807 times!
That equates to an asset bandwidth usage of:
(392,807 requests) * (38 KB per request) = 14,926,666 KB or
As an example, we can transform this image to WEBP format by appending the following parameter to the URL:
?fm=webp
https://images.ctfassets.net/6pezt69ih962/1ePoDY3XIuYleBQGNKFOTS/35de41a77844d9c3da954074021deeb3/The_Hunt_-_Hero?fm=webp
If we load that newly transformed image, you‚Äôll see it looks the same. Only now, it‚Äôs a WEBP file type instead of JPEG. If we downloaded the image, we would see the new file size is 21 KB.
That equates to an asset bandwidth
savings
of:
(392,807 requests) * (38 KB - 21 KB per request) = 6,677,719 KB or
6.68 GB saved

But wait! There is still more we can do. Maybe this image is going to load on a mobile device and, since the screen is smaller, we can reduce the quality by 50% since people won‚Äôt notice a small difference.¬†Let's add another parameter:
https://images.ctfassets.net/6pezt69ih962/1ePoDY3XIuYleBQGNKFOTS/35de41a77844d9c3da954074021deeb3/The_Hunt_-_Hero?fm=webp&q=50
If we load that newly transformed image, it still looks the same, only with a small quality degradation. But we reduced the file size to 18 KB.
That reduces the asset bandwidth by nearly
half
when compared to the original amount. That savings can be significant!

abstract.en: If customers exceed their contract's monthly asset bandwidth limits, they will accrue additional charges. Help your customers understand how to avoid overages by using the Images API.

content.value: What is bandwidth?
Bandwidth

refers to the amount of data that is transferred between a server and the user. For example, when you load a webpage in your browser, data from a server is sent to your computer, and this data is measured as the number of bits transferred during a period of seconds. Most often, the largest pieces of data sent are images and videos, but can be any file type, including the files containing the code that runs the website.
What are asset bandwidth overages?
Every Contentful customer has a monthly asset bandwidth limit that is determined by the terms of their subscription, as documented publicly on the
Usage Limits
help page.

If a customer uses more asset bandwidth than their contract allows, they will still be able to request assets from Contentful, but they will be charged for any asset bandwidth that exceeds their monthly limit.
Asset bandwidth usage is counted across
all

spaces and environments that make up your customer‚Äôs Contentful organization. It‚Äôs possible for one space to ‚Äúeat up‚Äù the usage for all other spaces, so we encourage space Administrators to collaborate and create a plan for asset utilization.
How is asset bandwidth calculated?

Each time an asset is requested from Contentful, we count the total transferred bytes for that request toward the total monthly asset bandwidth.¬†For example, when an end user visits a customer's website, every image on that site that is delivered by Contentful will count toward the asset bandwidth total.
Note,
it does not matter
if the asset is cached or uncached
on the CDN. We will always look at the transferred bytes
before
the cache to calculate usage.
Use the Images API to reduce asset bandwidth
The
Images API

allows the retrieval and on-the-fly manipulation of image files referenced from assets in Contentful. This allows customers to upload one high quality image to Contentful and then rely on the API to deliver smaller, cropped and manipulated images to the end experience.
Use of the Images API requires developer effort; just as developers use the Content Delivery API to retrieve entries from Contentful, they should use the Images API to request images.
Change file formats
Using the Images API to
change file formats
, such as converting a JPEG image to WebP or AVIF format, should result in a smaller asset size which can lower the total bandwidth used. This
blog post
discusses the benefits of these formats.
Change image quality
Lower the
quality of the image
in order to reduce the overall image file size, expressed as a percentage between 1:100. The lower the number, the lower the quality.
Other manipulations
Resize and crop
images
Specify focus areas
of images
Change the background color
How can I check if my customer is using the Images API?
Help your customers understand if and how they are using the Images API by using the
Asset Bandwidth Consumption Deep Dive
dashboard in Tableau (new as of Feb 22, 2024). This dashboard covers only the previous 6 months of bandwidth usage.
NOTE:
The following step-by-step guide follows the
Contentful Asset Bandwidth Review
dashboard in Redash. Redash is being replaced by
Top Assets for a Space
in Tableau, however the Tableau dashboard does not include what Images API parameters are used, only whether image transformations are used at all. Even if an asset show
True
for in the
Image Transformations
column, this does not mean that the transformations used are affecting the asset's size. These instructions will be updated to reflect the new dashboard once this
Image Transformations
data is updated to include the API parameters, but the concepts still apply.
What are other causes of high bandwidth?
As mentioned, assets over 20MB are sent as files and cannot be transformed by the Images API. In fact, those large images will be served by the
downloads.ctfassets.net
domain like other files, and not the
images.ctfassets.net
domain.
For Premium customers, Contentful allows users to upload files that are up to 1,000 MB in size (see our
Technical Limits
to learn more).
Typical large files include:
Videos:
Generally, we recommend customers use a dedicated service, like Wistia or YouTube, to host their videos. The blog post
Three ways to integrate video with Contentful
goes into detail.
Files:
These include types like PDFs that may contain embedded assets that could lead to large asset bandwidth usage
Audio:
Like video, these files (such as MP3) can be quite large and use a lot of bandwidth to deliver
What else can customers do?
Customers can see an
Asset bandwidth overview
under the
Usage
tab in their organization. Information provided includes:
Billing period information, including number of days remaining in the period
Total included asset bandwidth
Used asset bandwidth amounts that are aligned with customer billing periods and updated daily
Upcoming improvements to this dashboard include displaying the top 25 assets consuming the most bandwidth, and usage alerts timed for when asset usage reaches 80% and 100% of plan thresholds.

Aside from bandwidth consumption issues, customers may have further asset governance, usage, or tracking needs beyond what Contentful offers. In these cases, we recommend use of a dedicated digital asset management (DAM) tool such as Brandfolder, Bynder, or Cloudinary. We offer several app integrations with third-party DAMs in the
Contentful Marketplace

abstract.en: Tactical playbooks to guide field members through the steps needed to educate customers on product features. These will be created for each major new release so that we have the resources to GTM.

content.value: Current Challenges
Contentful regularly releases new features without fully enabling the Field team on how to identify, pitch, and train customers on how to use them.
CSMs have consistently mentioned that they don‚Äôt have the required technical enablement to confidently go to market with features.
After onboarding customers on these new features, we also don‚Äôt have any way to measure their success and ensure they are maximizing their usage.
Adoption Playbooks

Tactical playbooks that scalably guide field members through the steps needed to educate customers on a product feature and adopt it. These will be created for each major new release so that we have the resources to go to market.
Playbooks are designed for existing customers and walk through:
Communication:
Informing and educating the customer about the feature
Demo:
Walk through the capabilities on a call with the customer
Next Steps:
Share resources and follow-up actions on how the customer can implement it themselves
Knowledge Hub

This website is an internal resource built on Contentful by the Product Adoption and Growth team to enable field team members to proactively go to their customers with details on product features, such as the target customer, use cases, best practices, implementation details, and other helpful resources.
Each feature we highlight with Adoption Playbooks will point to this Knowledge Hub as the de facto internal repository for information on product functionality.
Running Playbooks in Gainsight

Playbooks in Gainsight will guide you through the steps to execute an Adoption Playbook from Knowledge Hub so that you can scalably engage your customers and track the progress on each one. Rather than assign the CTAs for accounts, the idea is to empower CSMs to create Playbooks for customers that they think would benefit the most from specific functionality.
