content.value: Advanced Caching (aka ‚Äúcache fallback‚Äù) provides two additional cache configuration options,
stale-when-rate-limited
and
stale-while-revalidate
, that enable our delivery APIs to serve stale data following a purge event until the cache is repopulated.

This behavior exchanges data freshness in favor of performance, and whether it makes sense for a particular customer is dependent on several factors, including their publishing frequency, visitor traffic, and business needs.
Eligible customers
Advanced caching is available to customers on our Scale and High Availability platforms (v2 pricing), and our Premium and Premium Plus plans (v3 pricing).
Internal note:
While advanced caching is limited to these pricing platforms, it is not technically tied to them, and can be enabled for any space.
Activation
Advanced caching is activated per space by the infrastructure team upon customer request. Customers must submit a
support ticket
, or their internal representatives (Account Executive, Customer Success Manager) can open a Zendesk ticket for Infrastructure support.
The support ticket should include the following:
Name and ID of the space for which advanced caching should be enabled
Documentation including the customer use case and reasons for seeking activation.
Selection of one or both configuration options:
Stale-when-rate-limited
Stale-while-revalidate
Verification of customer fitness
Depending on a customer‚Äôs delivery architecture, advanced caching may not be an effective option for them. We can take the following steps to further verify that this feature will fit their needs.
Post-sales
For current Premium or Premium Plus platform customers, Customer Support Engineers (CSE) can use the
Advanced Caching verification questions
as a way to help determine fitness for the feature.
When enabling advanced caching, CSEs must always provide the following
disclaimer

Contentful provides advanced caching as an optional feature to help its customers achieve their implementation goals, but due to the details of your delivery architecture, it may or may not serve your particular needs. Enabling this feature is not a guarantee that it will fit your use case. If you would like in-depth technical assistance from a dedicated expert, Contentful offers Professional Services engagements.
Pre-sales

For customers who are considering upgrading to Premium or Premium Plus platforms for this feature, we must validate internally that advanced caching is the right solution for them. Account Executives may confer with a Solution Engineer (SE) in these cases.
Additional consultation: Pre- and post-sales
If a case requires further advice and there is an active Professional Services (PS) engagement, CSEs or SEs may request consultation with a Solution Architect (SA).
If there is no active PS engagement, an unpaid PS ticket can be raised. Note: all PS time must be pre-approved by a manager before an SA can speak with customers.
See
Implementation details
for specific recommendations regarding the configuration options.
Advanced Caching is implemented in our Fastly configuration.

Advanced caching is enabled per space, and affects all environments within that space. Therefore, all environments in that space will return stale data according to the chosen configuration option. Enabling advanced caching for one space in an organization does not automatically enable it for any other spaces in that organization.

Advanced caching does not affect cache purging strategy. Publish/unpublish events will still only purge the cache for that environment, and other environments within that space will remain unaffected. Creating new environments and switching environment aliases will continue to purge the cache as normal.¬†
Cache configuration options
Stage 0: Stale-on-error
Stale-on-error is not a part of advanced caching, and it is automatically enabled for all spaces.
Behavior
If the backend would return a 5XX error and stale data is available, instead the API returns the stale response rather than the error. This behavior helps to ensure content is delivered, if possible.
Header returned
X_CACHE=HIT
Stage 1: Stale-when-rate-limited
Behavior
The delivery APIs are rate limited, meaning they only allow a certain number of uncached requests per second before a
429 response code
is returned. With the stale-when-rate-limited option enabled, stale content will be returned instead of the 429 code whenever possible while the cache rebuilds.
Header returned
X_CACHE=HIT
Good candidates

Customers who experience consistently high traffic (> 100K requests / month) and frequent publish/unpublish events (multiple times / day) can benefit from stale-when-rate-limited behavior to ensure their visitors continue to experience performant response times during cache rebuilds. When using stale-when-rate-limited, customers favor performance over data freshness.
For example, a highly trafficked news website which publishes multiple new articles per day can avoid introducing increased load times for its existing articles each time a new change is made.
Poor candidates

Stale-when-rate-limited will not improve requests that include unique variables, such as a timestamp, or combinations of variables that constitute unique requests, such as groups of entries selected by end users using facets. In these cases, the request will always bypass the cache, and therefore no stale content is available.
Stage 2: Stale-while-revalidate
Behavior

Normally, a request for an object that has been marked as invalid in the cache will cause the backend to ‚Äúrevalidate‚Äù, i.e. it will compare whether the response has changed, and if it has, it will update the cache. Revalidating a request can be nearly as expensive as serving a new, uncached request (120-200 ms).

With stale-while-revalidate enabled, stale content (when available) will be served until the revalidation process completes. Customers using this option are choosing to prefer that responses for the same request are performant even if stale data is returned. This behavior is only happening in the first 60 seconds after the cache was invalidated. Requests arriving later will be revalidated and served fresh data.
Header returned
X_CACHE=HIT
Good candidates

Customers who require low latency responses as an important business need will benefit from the performance increases provided by stale-while-revalidate, especially if the requests are expensive to compute, or may be geographically far removed from a CDN point-of-presence. This is particularly useful if the customer anticipates a large number of identical requests at the same time.

For example, a video game publisher may wish to make a product announcement at a large event, and simultaneously publish content related to that product to their website. The customer anticipates a large number of visitors to the same URL at the time of the announcement. In preparation, the customer created the content with a ‚Äúcoming soon‚Äù message. After the content is updated for the event, visitors to the URL will see the ‚Äúcoming soon‚Äù message (rather than experiencing long load times) until the cache revalidates and the fresh content is available.
Business limitations
No self service provisioning
The feature cannot be enabled by the customer or internally by support or sales (unlike other features that can be enabled from the Gatekeeper admin).
The infrastructure team must provision advanced caching through a hands-on process.
Naming

Using ‚Äústages‚Äù, i.e. stage 1 and 2, to define the cache configuration options is misleading. These caching options are not progressions of one another, but rather are independent functions, and they can be enabled in any order and combination. Using the functional naming, stale-when-rate-limited and stale-while-revalidate, is more descriptive and accurate.
Incompatibility with customer-side caches

Customers using their own cache in combination with advanced caching cannot reliably ensure that they are receiving fresh content from Contentful when they rebuild. For example, a customer could use a webhook to purge their own cache when a publish event occurs in Contentful, however, even if the Contentful cache successfully purges before requests from the external cache are made, Contentful may still serve stale content.

Further, customers cannot tell if stale content is returned using the X_CACHE header. Using internal logs, we can tell if stale content is served, however customers will see X_CACHE=HIT with stale data.
Lack of structured product representation
This product began as a one-off request from a customer, and the organic growth in its adoption was not accompanied by creating structured internal or external communication or governance.
Technical limitations
Stale content is not always available

Stale content can only be served if an individual response has been cached at least once. For example, since draft entries have never been published, no responses for those entries will exist in the cache and no stale content will be available to return.
Non-detectable on customer side

Stale responses are indistinguishable from non-stale responses on the client side, i.e. advanced caching will always return a X_CACHE=HIT header. For this reason, advanced caching should never be used with customer-side caches.
Internally, stale responses can be identified in our Fastly logs.
Low probability of inconsistent purge
There is a known low-probability race condition that impacts purging for spaces that have advanced caching enabled. The impact is mitigated by the frequency of purging.¬†

label.en: Does advanced caching use a separate cache?

content.value: No, advanced caching provides different behavior for the same cache that is used for serving the CDA and GraphQL APIs.

internalName.en: Advanced caching > FAQs > When stale content available

label.en: What does ‚ÄúWhen stale content is available‚Äù mean?

content.value: Stale content can only be served if an individual response has been cached at least once. For example, since draft entries have never been published, no responses for those entries will exist in the cache and no stale content will be available to return.

Also note that each Point of Presence (POP) is a separate cache. That means that if the customer sends a request form one part of the world, and it gets cached in POP A, it can be only used as stale content in POP A . If the same request arrives from another part of the world to POP B, there will be no available stale response in POP B.

internalName.en: Advanced caching > FAQs > Customer visibility into stale data

label.en: How can the customer tell if they are served stale data?

content.value: Customers are unable to determine if a request returns stale data. With both stale-when-rate-limited and stale-while-revalidate enabled, the response header returned will be X_CACHE=HIT.¬†

internalName.en: Advanced caching > FAQs > How tell if turned on

label.en: How can the customer tell if the feature is turned on for their space?

content.value: Customers cannot validate that advanced caching is enabled for their space; there is neither an indicator in the web app UI, nor one in the response traffic itself. In case of stale-when-rate-limited, they should see a decided drop in 429 responses after the feature is enabled.¬†
If a customer wants to perform a load test to understand the capabilities and limits of advanced caching, they should coordinate with the infrastructure team first by opening a support ticket.

internalName.en: Advanced caching > FAQs > How old is stale content?

label.en: How old is the stale content that is served?

content.value: Stale content will be as old as the last successful request before the most recent cache invalidation event. Essentially, stale content is one cache invalidation event behind the freshest data. For example, if the last successful cache for a request was six hours ago, and a new publish event causes the cache to invalidate, the stale content returned for that request will be six hours old.
Since the TTL for the cache is 30 days, the technical limit on stale content is 30 days old at the extreme.¬†

internalName.en: Advanced Caching > FAQs > What traffic criteria determines good fit?

label.en: What visitor traffic criteria should a customer meet to make advanced caching a good option?

content.value: Customers with consistently high traffic (> 100K visitors / month) and frequent un/publish events may be good candidates for stale-when-rate-limited.
Customers who value consistently low latency responses, especially during expected high traffic times, may be good candidates for stale-while-revalidate.
See the above
Stage 1: Stale-when-rate-limited
and
Stage 2: Stale-while-revalidate
sections for more details.

internalName.en: Advanced Caching > FAQs > Use with customer caches

label.en: Can advanced caching be used with customer-side caches?

content.value: Customers should not use additional caches in conjunction with advanced caching. There is no way for customers to determine if stale data is returned from Contentful, and therefore there is no way to ensure that additional caches are not serving stale data as fresh.

internalName.en: Advanced Caching > FAQs > Use with SSG

label.en: Can advanced caching be used with static site generation (SSG)?

content.value: Advanced caching should not be used with SSG. By definition, SSG generates static HTML pages at build time. Any cache invalidation event will require a new build in order to serve fresh data.

internalName.en: Advanced Caching > FAQs > Application to environments

label.en: Does advanced caching apply to all environments in a space?

content.value: Advanced caching is enabled per space, and affects all environments within that space.

Advanced caching does not affect cache purging strategy. Cache invalidation events will still only purge the cache for that environment, and other environments within that space will remain unaffected.

internalName.en: Advanced Caching > FAQs > Number of records

label.en: How does the number of records in a space affect advanced caching?

content.value: It doesn‚Äôt. The performance of individual uncached requests is not directly dependent on the size of the space, and instead depends on factors such as geographical location and the complexity of the requests.

label.en: How can a customer ensure their architecture is compatible with advanced caching?

content.value: Please see
Verification of customer fitness
in the
Target Customer
section of this article.

abstract.en: Asking these questions will help verify whether Advanced Caching is an appropriate option for customers that request to enable it.

content.value: Overview
This document is intended to aid Customer Support Engineers to verify that
Advanced Caching
is an appropriate option for customers that request to enable it. Asking the customer these questions will help avoid misalignment with customer expectations.
NOTE: Advanced Caching is only available on the Content Delivery API (CDA) and GraphQL Content API.
Disclaimer
In all cases when enabling advanced caching, provide the following disclaimer:

Contentful provides advanced caching as an optional feature to help its customers achieve their implementation goals, but due to the details of your delivery architecture, it may or may not serve your particular needs. Enabling this feature is not a guarantee that it will fit your use case. If you would like in-depth technical assistance from a dedicated expert, Contentful offers Professional Services engagements.
What issue is the customer trying to solve with advanced caching?
Remember, advanced caching trades data freshness in favor of performance. Does a customer‚Äôs use case align with one or both of these options?
Stale-when-rate-limited
Customers with consistently high traffic (> 100K visitors / month) and frequent un/publish events¬† (> once / day) may be good candidates for
stale-when-rate-limited
For example, a highly trafficked news website which publishes multiple new articles per day can avoid introducing increased load times for its existing articles each time a new change is made.
Stale-while-revalidate
Customers who require low latency responses as an important business need will benefit from the performance increases provided by
stale-while-revalidate

, especially if the requests are expensive to compute, or may be geographically far removed from a CDN point-of-presence. This is particularly useful if the customer anticipates a large number of identical requests at the same time, such as for a scheduled product release.
Is the customer using any caching in addition to the Contentful CDN?

Customers should not use additional caches in conjunction with advanced caching. There is no way for customers to determine if stale data is returned from Contentful, and therefore there is no way to ensure that additional caches are not serving stale data as fresh.
Is the customer using static site generation (SSG)?
Advanced caching should not be used with SSG. By definition, SSG generates static HTML pages at build time. Any cache invalidation event will require a new build in order to serve fresh data.
Is the customer sending queries to Contentful that include unique parameter values?
Advanced caching will not improve requests that include unique
query parameter values

, such as a timestamp, or combinations of variables that constitute unique requests, such as groups of entries selected by end users using facets. In these cases, the request will always bypass the cache, and therefore no stale content is available.

abstract.en: Learn how best to support these a Contentful project when planning for, implementing, and using Studio Experiences by following these guiding principles in four steps.

content.value: Guiding principles
While
Studio - Experiences

presents a new way for creators to assemble the visual display of their content, the core tenants and value propositions of Contentful remain the same. This article outlines how best to support these Contentful foundations when planning for, implementing, and using Experiences.
With Studio - Experiences, just as with the Contentful Platform, achieving the best results depends on careful planning, consideration, and discipline by digital teams.
Cross-team collaboration
The most successful organizations share a clear understanding of goals, methods, and reasons for building with Contentful across the digital team.

In Platform, content creators must collaborate with developers and designers when building the content model in order to ensure requirements are met for all, including usability, maintainability, and delivery.
In Studio, developers, designers, content creators, and marketers must collaboratively determine what design options the experience should provide and how content maps to visual components.
Well-structured content and design

In Platform, a well-structured content model empowers content reuse, omnichannel delivery, and consistency with a create-once-publish-everywhere capability. The purpose content serves must be understood clearly in order to be used most effectively.
In Studio, well-structured design provides context to structured content by assembling it into meaningful presentations based on brand guidelines.
Prioritization of the authoring experience

No content team can truly be successful unless the authoring experience is clear, straightforward, and alleviates decision-making fatigue. Creators must be able to curate messaging, go to market quickly, and progressively experiment.

In Platform, we support creators through a meaningful balance between complexity and ease of use by ensuring clarity of purpose in the content model. A good Platform build means creators understand the purpose of each content type and how entries work together to achieve omni-channel delivery.

In Studio, we support creators through a meaningful balance between complexity and ease of use by ensuring we provide the right tools for visual assembly. A good Studio build means creators can quickly leverage existing designs, manipulate them for their use case, and bind semantic content from entries.
Keep these principles in mind as we follow these four steps to set up and build with Studio Experiences.
Step 1:
Identify the use case
Step 2:
Consider the content model
Step 3:
Craft the experience interface
Step 4:
Assemble an experience
The ideal vs. reality

Every customer content model and application architecture will be different, which is a combined expression of varying requirements, use cases, preferences, well and poorly exercised best practices, and team collaboration styles. In short, who knows what they‚Äôve got and how able they are to change it.

By providing a baseline of best practices regarding how a content model, design system, and team workflows should be considered in terms of Experiences, we‚Äôre establishing guidelines against which to measure a customer‚Äôs situation, and in turn provide support for our recommendations. These recommendations will evolve along with the product.
Terminology
Studio:
The name of the product that will include different capabilities, of which Experiences is the first one.
Experiences:
The first capability under the Studio product, Experiences is a tool for creating visual layouts within Contentful.
Experience type:
Analogous to a ‚Äúcontent type‚Äù, the Experience type includes the canvas, registered components, patterns, and fields on the type itself, which appear under the Settings tab
Experience:
With a lowercase ‚Äúe‚Äù, an "experience" is analogous to a content "entry". It is an individual instance of an Experience type.
Canvas:
The drag-and-drop interface where an experience is assembled using components and patterns
Component:
A single piece of a design system representing a meaningful visual item that is registered in code
Pattern:
A reusable design piece created within Experiences, comprised of components
Content binding:
Population of fields in components and patterns with content from entries
Settings:
Appearing as a tab in Experiences, it displays a form editor for fields that appear on the Experience type
Layers:
A hierarchical view of sections and components in the canvas
Step 1: Identify the use case

Each Experience type must have a clear use case defined that is specific and well-understood. This not only provides clarity for content creators about what purpose the Experience type serves in their digital application ‚Äì e.g. campaign landing pages, product editorial pages ‚Äì but also informs how the Experience type itself should be structured ‚Äì i.e. the
design elements and components
available to assemble an entry.
Why do this?

Studio - Experiences provides a new layer of design flexibility on top of Contentful‚Äôs foundation in structured content, but with it comes a renewed need for discipline from customers to ensure they‚Äôre reaching for the right tool to perform their tasks at hand.

The temptation to use a single Experience type for multiple use cases (‚Äúif I have complete design flexibility, couldn't I use it for anything?‚Äù) can quickly lead to the Experience type becoming the junk drawer, full of the content equivalent of discarded rolls of half-used tape, scattered pens and paper clips, random phone charger cords, and who knows what else. Instead, the Experience type should serve as the silverware drawer; we know what we‚Äôll find in there, what we use it for, and we‚Äôre careful to keep it that way.

When Experience types are built to serve every need, you run the risk of repeating the mistakes of legacy CMSs. Without differentiation, we cannot scale, measure, evaluate, or improve experiences. Encourage customers to think one year in the future ‚Äì what will be the hallmarks of unmanaged content chaos? What mess would they not want to clean up? A good activity for aligning on this is a
Sailboat Premortem
See
Appendix A: Here be dragons
for a review of the relationship between design consistency and content volume, and how it influences use case selection.
How do we do it?
Use these questions to assess whether a use case is a good fit for Experiences.¬† A use case may represent a new opportunity, or could replace an existing content type.
Does this use case serve a single, web-based channel?
Experiences combine presentation with content in a single JSON field, which makes it difficult to display the same entry in different ways in different contexts.

In contrast, a content type like "Promotion" may have fields that pertain to all channels (like price or product) alongside fields specific to a single channel (like web display or digital signage display). The web and signage frontends can then select the appropriate fields for their application from the same Promotion entry.
Furthermore, the Experiences Canvas renders in an iframe that embeds a web view. The frontend application will need to be able to render as a web based version in order to display.
What needs for design flexibility or variability does this use case have?

Just like any system, there will be tradeoffs between achieving the desired flexibility and maintaining ease of use. Outlining both the capabilities of the system and the needs of the end user will ensure that the right level of complexity promotes the right level of creativity.

Work with both content and design teams to specific areas in the potential use case where design flexibility needs are anticipated, and where design experimentation is desired. Often, there will be conflicts between one team's goals over the other; as you move through this process, record these findings along with the reasons why.
What level of design consistency is required by the business with this use case?
Identify areas in the use case where the design is not expected to, or should not, change. Note what percentage of this use case relies on predefined structure for its display.
Since experiences are built piece by piece, layouts that retain consistency based on structured content types are a poor fit for Experiences at this time.
How often do I need design variability when creating experiences for this use case?

Understand the frequency with which designs for this use case need to be altered. For example, the header banner for product editorial pages is updated once per week or more, and each update requires slight design changes.
What qualities of an existing content model may indicate a use case?
An assembly content type using multi-reference fields to achieve flexible layouts by referencing design-oriented content types
Content types using a multitude of fields to represent design options, such color, alignment, sizing, etc.
Multiple variation of the same content type to achieve different designs
Content models that are deeply nested to achieve design requirements
What is the shelf life of content in this experience?

Often content or particular content assemblies, especially related to marketing or events, is not meant to remain published for an extended period, and this can typically coincide with needs for additional design flexibility. Also, a team may wish to try new layouts or design options and cannot wait for the development cycle to bring them to market.
How long is content for the use case expected to live in the market?
Is the use case based around rapid prototyping or experimentation with design?
See
Appendix B: Assessing design needs
for a tool that can help facilitate determining a use case.
What are some examples?
Content with a limited time in market
Examples
Campaign landing pages
Email campaigns

Note: while a good use case, email delivery will require exporting React components to email-friendly markup, and integrating with an API-friendly email client, like Sendgrid. This use case needs to be proven further, but has potential.
Justification
This content presents specific initiatives with the intent to increase awareness or drive conversions, and they require custom layouts and design changes to do so
Storytelling that pushes design
Examples
Product editorial pages
Product launch pages
Event pages
About us pages
Justification
Each page of a type presents similar content, but the design needs to adjust to tell the story in different ways (ex: product pages like Apple‚Äôs
iPhone
Watch
iPad
Each page uses components from our design system, but uses different styles to convey a new meaning (ex: events like
Storylines
Each page uses its own design, and is unlike any others (snowflake pages, such as about us)

Without Experiences, authors rely on multiple content types and/or design options which are provided as content type fields to provide flexibility. Authors find themselves frustrated and wishing for a visual editor.
Microsites
Examples
Events sites
Campaign sites
Product/service sites
Justification
These pages present specific initiatives with the intent to increase awareness or drive conversions, and they require custom layouts and design changes to do so
A microsite needs a separate look and feel to cater to a particular audience
Rapid prototyping
Examples
Landing pages
Justification
Marketers wish to experiment with new layouts without waiting for dev involvement
Step 2: Consider the content model

Studio - Experiences provides a way for creators to craft the visual display of their content directly within Contentful. Fundamentally, this characterizes the relationship between well-structured data and the context in which that data is displayed. We typically think of this in terms of
topics
‚Äì the things an application is about, e.g. product features, promotions, blog posts ‚Äì and
assemblies
‚Äì the way topics are combined to convey a particular meaning, e.g. campaign landing pages, product editorial pages.
Content vs. presentation
In order to achieve design flexibility in Contentful without Experiences, we often conflate content with presentation by building content models that:

Employ an assembly content type (ex: Landing Page) that uses multi-reference fields to achieve flexible layouts. These fields often reference design-oriented content types (ex: Card Grid, Duplex, Hero Banner)

Include fields on content types that provide display options ‚Äì such as alignment, color, size, etc. ‚Äì to affect display for individual entries of that type. Often these options only pertain to a single context, such as choosing what side of a Duplex to display the image.

With Experiences, however, there is a clear separation of concerns between content and presentation: content lives in entries represented by the content model, and display of that content lives with the experience. This allows us to build content types that represent what the content ‚Äùis‚Äù rather than how it should be displayed, which leads to improving clarity, and supporting omni-channel delivery and content reuse.
To illustrate this, let‚Äôs consider a component typically found on marketing websites, the Card Grid.

Each Card Grid consists of a heading along with a series of Cards, each with an image, heading, and description text. In the content model, we can imagine a Card Grid content type that includes a multi-reference field to Card entries which allows us to achieve this visual display.
If we consider this further, however, we see that the content for each Card is actually a product feature. This raises a couple of questions:
Could we use this card design style to highlight other content, like a blog post, value statement, or sales promotion?
Could we decide to display this same content, the product feature, in a different way that isn‚Äôt a card?

The answer to both questions is ‚Äúabsolutely‚Äù. This affords us the opportunity to employ content types that speak to the purpose of the content ‚Äì like Blog Post,¬† Value Statement, or Promotion ‚Äì rather than how it should display, such as Card. And since we now know exactly what our content is, we can choose to display it how we like as a separate decision.

Finally, what would happen if the team decided later that all mentions of a product feature should link back to a prefiltered page listing all products that share that feature? If the product feature content is scattered across several different content types (card, accordion, hero), it becomes difficult or impossible to manually or programmatically connect product features to products.
Content modeling for Experiences at a glance:
Content types should represent the content they contain, i.e. lean into the concept of topics

Remember, not all fields included in a content type need to be rendered in every context an entry of that type is displayed, e.g. we don‚Äôt display the body of a blog post when it‚Äôs rendered in a card. Keep fields that belong to a topic with its content type.
Design components
registered in the Experience type do not need to correspond 1:1 with a content type, e.g. a Card
design component
can be used to display any content with the appropriate field types; it does not need to rely on a Card
content type
See
Appendix C: The ‚Äúis-ness‚Äù of content
for a discussion about clarity of purpose with content.
Assess a content model for Experiences
Given the
intended use case
for an Experience type, we can apply a series of questions to understand how well the content model supports our goals.
First
, determine what content types and which fields exist in the model that support our needs.
What content will an experience need to include?
Where in the content model is this content represented? Is content missing?
Second
, determine how discoverable the required content is. When
binding content
in an experience, creators must confidently know which content types to search for and what search terms to use to locate the correct content.

They also must understand how content entries relate to one another in the model. For example, a creator may need to add Product Feature content in an experience, but if the content does not yet exist and they create a new entry in the experience and bind it, do they also need to add that Product Feature entry as a reference in a Product content type?
How does a creator find entries of this content when it exists? How do they know they‚Äôve found the correct entry?
What steps does a content creator need to take to ensure new entries are properly discoverable, or appropriately linked to other entries?
Third
, understand where else this content appears so that we know how changes made to it in the experience may affect other areas where it appears.
Where is this content reused, such as in other content types, delivery channels, or Spaces?
Finally
, determine whether there is content that doesn‚Äôt belong in the content model at all, and safely can be
manually entered
in the experience.
Is there content that will never be reused, does not relate to any other content, and will have a limited time in market?
Step 3: Craft the Experience interface
Studio - Experiences provides options both for registering design components that are developed in code, and creating
patterns

that live within the experience itself. Registered components and patterns are the building blocks with which creators assemble an experience, but each has characteristics that make them suitable for different purposes.

Careful consideration must be given to deciding what design tools to include in order to ensure a positive authoring experience, adherence to brand guidelines, and support for the goals of the Experience type.
See
Implementation details
in the Studio - Experiences product article for dev guides.
What are registered components?
Registered components
refers to design system items that are added in code using the
Experiences SDK
. This means that these design items must be added to the Experience type by a developer before they can be used by creators.

Rather than broadly registering every item in a design system, we should instead evaluate which of those design items provide the necessary tools to accomplish our goals in the Experience type. To support this discussion, we categorize the design items we are considering for our Experience type into two categories:
elements
and
components
Elements

These are the smallest, meaningful pieces from the design system that can be combined to create larger design items. We‚Äôre using the term ‚Äúelements‚Äù rather than "atoms‚Äù, a term which is specific to
atomic design
and not widely understood except by design professionals, but their intent is the same.

As the most basic building blocks in the Experience type, elements appear in components that exist in code, and will be used to create and augment patterns. Elements provide creators with the granular flexibility needed to assemble the visual display of an entry in novel ways.
Studio provides several default elements as part of the SDK called Basics ‚Äì e.g. Heading, Text, Button ‚Äì but it‚Äôs recommended to disable these defaults and substitute them with custom ones. See
Which to use: registered components or patterns?
for further discussion.
Consider these example elements, along with design options, content fields, and sample content types that could be used to populate them with bound content.
Name

Components

Components combine elements into larger items that are well represented in the design system. While elements provide granular control over the design, e.g. adding an additional button, components provide more complex, predefined layouts that form distinct sections of the page, e.g. a hero banner or card grid. Studio - Experiences does not provide any default components; they must be registered by using the Experiences SDK.
Consider these example components.
Name
Options
Fields
Content examples
Header Banner - Hero
Palette (ex: Light/Dark or Brand Colors)¬†
Heading:
Plain Text (short or long)

Promo cards

Testimonial

Plain Text (short or long)

Plain text¬†

Quote
Determine which components to register

Comprehensive design systems include every visual item required by an organization to create their digital experiences, but we likely should not register every component with Studio. Instead, we need to keep in mind our intended use case, as well as think critically about what building blocks represent our core requirements.

They can be thought of as blueprints, a visual language, or structured framework that helps ensure visual consistency, while also reducing the time needed to recreate components when assembling experiences or interfaces.
First

, gather example pages for the Experience type use case and identify all design system items that are used, as well as any items that are expected to be used. At this stage, we want to identify the building blocks that comprise the page design and how they‚Äôre intended to be used. Note if the same design component appears in different contexts, or has design variations that could be captured as options.
What are the smallest, meaningful elements needed to build this page?
Where do we see the same or similar components used with different types of content?
What components will we need to repeatedly reach for in order to build pages like this?
Second

, consider how stable the design of these components should be. Note which components should have more governance over their design, and which components should be able to accommodate the most design flexibility.
What components are the most stable design-wise?
What components need the most flexibility?
What design options should be available to each element and component?
Third

, determine what content is expected to appear in these design pieces to ensure component field types will properly support them, e.g. a rich text field in a content type cannot be bound to a simple text field in an Experiences component. Note that currently a component field cannot bind to a reference field in a content type.
What content examples pertain to the components?
What fields apply to this component, and how are they represented in my content model?
In future versions of Experiences, admins may also be able to set permissions by category, allowing certain roles access only to certain groups of components.
Registered components tips and tricks
The
component definition schema

allows for adding a thumbnail representation of the component along with a description, which will display as a tooltip on mouse hover. Add both to increase understanding of the component‚Äôs purpose for the user.
What are patterns?
Patterns

in Studio - Experiences are similar to registered components in that they are composed of smaller elements ‚Äì e.g. headings, text, images, buttons ‚Äì to form a larger design piece, such as a card or hero banner. In contrast to registered components which are created in code, patterns are assembled and saved directly within Studio. This allows maximum flexibility to create new components as needed without developer intervention (as long as the required elements and options have already been registered in code).
Patterns are:
Reusable design pieces, like components
Created by assembling existing elements and/or components in a new manner, and saving them
Globally updateable ‚Äì by editing a design pattern, creators can update every instance of that pattern where it is currently used in experiences
Individually changeable ‚Äì by decoupling an instance of a pattern from the parent pattern, its design can be altered without affecting any usage of that pattern in other entries
Which to use: registered components or patterns?
Registered components and patterns play a similar role in Experiences, so why do we have both, and when should a creator reach for one or the other?¬†
Components benefits
We have full control over how they are rendered in the frontend, which enables proper semantic markup and accessibility affordances

We can include options in the Experiences design palette that pertain to the component as a whole, allowing advanced manipulation of its appearance, or even the attribution of interactive elements, such as provided in a select list
They represent a familiar, repeatedly used design piece which should be governed in a more prescriptive way, and in turn increases the speed and efficiency of assembling experiences
We can provide only the relevant elements and options for this component, eliminating decision-making weight from creator shoulders
Components drawbacks
Decisions for how these components should behave were made outside of the experience, and we cannot change them without developer intervention
Augmenting a registered component in the experience is limited ‚Äì the component must allow children in its schema, and only if so, only one ‚Äúslot‚Äù to add other elements will become available
Patterns benefits
Creators have full control over what elements to include and how to arrange them into a new component without developer intervention (we are still limited by the registered elements, however)
Creators can update a saved pattern to update every instance in which it is used
Creators can detach a single instance of a pattern in order to augment it without affecting other instances
Patterns drawbacks
It‚Äôs possible to assemble a pattern using structure and design elements in such a way that makes for poor markup, which is invisible to creators
Creators are still limited by the established components provided to them, and it‚Äôs difficult to impossible to provide advanced design options that apply to the pattern, such as interactive items
It's not possible to nest patterns within other patterns, which may somewhat limit reuse expectations
Structure components

The built-in structure components ‚Äì Section, Container, Columns ‚Äì provide layout boxes into which creators can arrange components. Unlike the built-in basic components, structure components cannot be disabled, and unlike the recommendation to create custom basic components, we recommend using the structure components as-is.

These layout pieces are fundamental to structuring patterns and the experience as a whole, and by diverging from these with custom options, customers may miss out on future product improvements affecting these. A drawback to this approach is not being able to customize styles.
See more about usage best practices in
Step 4: Assemble an experience
Design palette decisions

When registering components, we have the opportunity to define what style options should be available for each component. The Experiences SDK provides several built-in styles that can be used ‚Äì e.g. font size, background color, margin ‚Äì but developers can, and should, also register custom styles.
By using custom styles, we improve adherence to brand guidelines, tailor options to those that are most appropriate for each component, and help guide creators in their decision making process.
Examples of custom styles:
Brand colors - register design system colors as options in the appropriate place, such as background colors for a button or light/dark options for a banner
Size -¬† rather than allowing creators to enter numeric pixel values, present options like Small, Medium, Large
Layout - present options that change the organization of a complex component, such allowing a card grid to be presented as a carousel or slider
Design tokens

The Experiences SDK also supports registering design tokens, and these tokens can then be used when defining style options for registered components. This not only supports brand consistency, but also more easily enables brand updates.¬†
Consider the markup

As noted, a benefit of registering components is that it allows full control over the semantic markup of complex components. However, by introducing certain style options we may inadvertently hinder understanding of the content by selecting options that result in inappropriate markup.
For example, a text component may offer style options that include Heading 1, Heading 2, Heading 3; and selecting these may result in the frontend application rendering
, and
tags. Headings in semantic markup should follow a
hierarchical structure
to support accessibility standards (and SEO), but by allowing creators to choose, we run the risk of breaking this hierarchy when creators select options based on their visual styles.
Experience Settings

All Experience types start with three required settings: a preview environment, a title, and a slug. The preview environment is required in order to use the Experiences canvas, but the title and slug settings operate similarly to fields on a content type. The frontend application can access these fields from the Experience object returned by the useFetchBySlug() function.

Add fields to the Experience type to provide additional content that belongs with experience entries, but should not be added via the canvas. This is a perfect use for SEO content, or other metadata that can influence use of the entry on the frontend.
Step 4: Assemble an experience

Assembling an experience consists of arranging components and patterns into the visual layout of the page, and then populating the fields in those design pieces with content. At this stage, we‚Äôve thoughtfully chosen what components should be available, how we‚Äôll make use of patterns, and what content types will be involved to create entries that serve our intended use case.
Now let‚Äôs review best practices regarding:
Using the built-in structure components along with registered components and patterns to lay out an experience
Binding content from fields in the content model to fields in experience components
Deciding when manual content entry is appropriate
Structure components

The built-in structure components ‚Äì Section, Container, Columns ‚Äì provide layout boxes into which creators can arrange components. Section and container are similar, but are intended for slightly different uses.
Section
Use section components for page layout. By default, sections are full-width components with no max-width value preconfigured.
Container

Use container components for other components in a group. By default, containers have a margin set to ‚Äúauto‚Äù with a preconfigured max-width of 1192 px. This means containers will be centered on the page when dropped on the canvas.
Columns
Use column components to arrange components in columnar or grid formats. Separate layouts should be used to arrange columns for different screen sizes, such as stacking components for mobile.
Bound vs. manual content

Content in an experience can be added from two sources: content entries, as represented in the content model, or manually within the experience itself. In almost all cases, content should come from entries in the content model, which is known as ‚Äúbinding‚Äù the content.
Why bind?
By leveraging content as it exists in the content model, we maintain the benefits of structured content that are core to Contentful, and ultimately equate to control over the content:
Content reuse
Multi-channel delivery
Content discoverability
Content maintainability and governance
Options for experimentation and personalization
Scalability
Content that is entered manually:
Only exists in the experience, and is stored in such a manner that it is essentially not retrievable from outside the experience
Cannot be searched from within Contentful
Cannot be localized within the experience
Cannot be managed from a central location, such as in a content list view
When could manual entry be a good idea?
Manually entered content forsakes the benefits of structured content. In some cases, however, manual entry may be the better choice.
Content used for rapid prototyping or testing¬†
Configuration content that only belongs with the experience, e.g. an end date used in an event countdown timer component
One-off content with a short time in market that will never be reused (but still, think this through)
R
oles & permissions: Who does what?
Experiences supports
three categories of permissions
based on the ability to view experiences, create/edit experiences using components and patterns, and the ability to create and edit patterns. Within the
Edit experiences
dialog, admins can also restrict which registered components are available to a particular role.

At a high level, we can divide customer roles into four personas: developers, designers, content creators, and marketers. Given the below responsibilities for each, we can begin determining which roles should be assigned permissions governing experience creation, editing, and publishing; layout management including pattern creation and updates; and content binding and manual entry.
Developers
Responsible for:
Implementing the Experience SDK and adding the <Experience> React component to the frontend application
Registering design components using the SDK to make them available for use in experiences according to agreed upon guidelines
Code maintenance, including updates to registered components
Designers
Responsible for:¬†
Building and maintaining the company brand in a design system, or similar repository
Informing what components should be available in the Experience type, and what style options are associated with them
Potentially managing patterns in the Experience type, by creating and editing them
Potentially designing page layouts in the Experience type for use by marketers
Content creators
Responsible for:
Creating, editing, and publishing content in the Contentful Platform
Marketers
Responsible for:
Assembling experiences by combining content and presentation
Coordinating with designers and content creators when assembling experiences
Potentially creating or adjusting patterns within the Experience type
Coordinating with the digital team on Experience type configuration adjustment decisions
Appendix A: Here be dragons

When organizations integrate visual page builders into their workflows without being disciplined about the reason and purpose for those tools, they risk losing control and understanding over their content and where it‚Äôs used. We can think of this in terms of content that needs either design consistency or flexibility, and the volume of that content.

Visual page builders often come into play when there is a high volume of content that also needs design flexibility. If we allow use of the page builder tool to invade the other quadrants shown in the diagram, we start to lose control and understanding.
Appendix B: Assessing design needs

Consider the level of consistency or flexibility required in regard to visual design when assessing both the fitness of a potential use case for Experiences, as well as how components should be represented in the Experience type, whether they are registered in code or created as patterns.

This assessment can be represented as a linear scale between design consistency and flexibility. Use cases that fall on the consistency side of the scale likely have a predefined layout structure with few to no options for design variability, such as blog posts. These use cases are a poor fit for Experiences.¬†

Other use cases may require some combination of consistency and flexibility, such as a product editorial page. Such pages may include a storytelling section aimed at selling the product that requires design flexibility, and a features section that is the same across all product pages.
Finally, a campaign landing page may require a different layout and design tweaks each time one is created. Such pages are a good use of Experiences.
Appendix C: The ‚Äúis-ness‚Äù of content

Content in its smallest form can be described as text, images, and audio. We can combine these elements to increase semantic meaning (ex: video is a combination of images and audio), but eventually we decrease meaning as more content is combined. The sweet spot for understanding is in the middle, where we have the most semantic clarity (ex: a case study is more specific than a web page).

internalName.en: Studio - Exp > Tip: ask designers for file

content.value: Tip! Engage the designers:

If the customer has a design system, ask the designers to create a file with all of the elements that they want Experiences users to build with. They may be comfortable with more atomic elements, or they may lean into predefined components.
Design systems
comprise a set of standards that define and provide a method for managing the visual elements that make up a digital experience or product.

internalName.en: Studio - Exp > Tip: use component groups

content.value: Tip! Group components together:

Registered components can be grouped by category in the Experiences interface allowing clearer understanding of the intended purpose for components, such as grouping all element types together as the basic building blocks in the experience, or grouping similar components together, such as banners or headers.
Design tokens

are a key-value pair that represent the small, repeated design decisions that make up a design system's visual style. Tokens replace static values, such as hex codes for color, with self-explanatory names.
Tokens can represent color, font styles, units of space, and whatever other style attributes are needed.

content.value: While it is possible to reference an experience from a content entry from a reference field, the results are suboptimal.

inspection mode and live editing
is not possible

internalName.en: Studio Exp - Known Limitations > Multiple <ExperienceRoot> components

label.en: Multiple instances of <ExperienceRoot> on a single page

content.value: If multiple <ExperienceRoot> components attempt to render for a single page, content from only the first experience entry will render for both components. This is a
known issue
and is being reviewed by Product.

This may surface with customers due to the fact that experience types can be used in reference fields on content types. A customer may then have a multi-reference or multiple reference fields that allow referencing experience types on a single content type. In every case where an experience is referenced, only the first returned experience will render.
